item.title: Can Placebos Work If You Know They're Placebos?
item.description: April 22, 2017 - NPR's Mary Louise Kelly asks writer Robert Siegel about "open label placebos" and whether placebos work even when patients know they're placebos. He wrote about his experience in Smithsonian Magazine.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 22, 2017 - NPR's Mary Louise Kelly asks writer Robert Siegel about "open label placebos" and whether placebos work even when patients know they're placebos. He wrote about his experience in Smithsonian Magazine. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/22/525188097/can-placebos-work-if-you-know-theyre-placebos

item.title: First Step To 'Eco-Grieving' Over Climate Change? Admit There's A Problem
item.description: April 22, 2017 - Psychologists say anxiety over climate change is making some people feel overwhelmed. To talk through their worries, a group in Utah is meeting weekly and the idea has drawn interest in other states.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 22, 2017 - Psychologists say anxiety over climate change is making some people feel overwhelmed. To talk through their worries, a group in Utah is meeting weekly and the idea has drawn interest in other states. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/22/524557600/first-step-to-eco-grieving-over-climate-change-admit-theres-a-problem

item.title: An Organizer Speaks About Reasons For A 'March For Science'
item.description:
April 22, 2017 - NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Lucky Tran, organizer of today's March for Science, occurring in a number of cities around the world.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/04/22/525188027/an-organizer-speaks-about-reasons-for-a-march-for-science

item.title: Chew On This For Earth Day: How Our Diets Impact The Planet
item.description: April 22, 2017 - The foods we choose to put on our plates — or toss away – could have more of an ecological impact than many of us realize.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 22, 2017 - The foods we choose to put on our plates — or toss away – could have more of an ecological impact than many of us realize. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/22/525113726/chew-on-this-for-earth-day-how-our-diets-impact-the-planet

item.title: March For Science Organizers Work To Maintain Non-Partisan Position
item.description: April 21, 2017 - A March for Science will be held Saturday in Washington, D.C., and hundreds of other cities in the U.S. Organizers say the march is a non-partisan celebration of science. It's meant to both encourage political leaders to fund science and rely on scientific evidence when making policy decisions. Critics worry the march will turn into an anti-Trump rally and paint scientists as just another interest group.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

Critics worry the march will turn into an anti-Trump rally and paint scientists as just another interest group. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/21/525110160/march-for-science-organizers-work-to-maintain-non-partisan-position

item.title: Lights Off, Blankets Out: Lyrid Meteor Shower Peaks Tonight
item.description: April 21, 2017 - Conditions on Friday night and before dawn on Saturday should be ideal for spotting the streaks of space debris — leftover particles from a comet that was last seen in 1861.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Maurice Conti: Can Machines Think And Feel For Themselves?
item.description: April 21, 2017 - Futurist Maurice Conti says we've entered a new era where machines and humans partner to do what neither can do alone. He calls it the "Augmented Age."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 21, 2017 - Futurist Maurice Conti says we've entered a new era where machines and humans partner to do what neither can do alone. He calls it the "Augmented Age." http://www.npr.org/2017/04/21/524702119/maurice-conti-can-machines-think-and-feel-for-themselves

item.title: Marco Annunziata: What Will Human-Machine Collaboration Mean For Our Jobs?
item.description: April 21, 2017 - GE's Chief Economist Marco Annunziata is optimistic about "the marriage of minds and machines" — provided we manage it the right way.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 21, 2017 - GE's Chief Economist Marco Annunziata is optimistic about "the marriage of minds and machines" — provided we manage it the right way. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/21/524701908/marco-annunziata-what-will-human-machine-collaboration-mean-for-our-jobs

item.title: Erik Brynjolfsson: In A Race With Machines, Can We Keep Up?
item.description: April 21, 2017 - MIT Professor Erik Brynjolfsson sees a bright future where machines serve as powerful tools and partners. But he says we can only shape this future if we keep up with the pace of innovation.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 21, 2017 - MIT Professor Erik Brynjolfsson sees a bright future where machines serve as powerful tools and partners. But he says we can only shape this future if we keep up with the pace of innovation. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/21/524700928/erik-brynjolfsson-in-a-race-with-machines-can-we-keep-up

item.title: Jeremy Howard: Will Artificial Intelligence Be The Last Human Invention?
item.description: April 21, 2017 - Jeremy Howard has studied machine learning for 25 years. He says artificial intelligence can help achieve amazing things. But he warns the impact on jobs may cause a great deal of social instability.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 21, 2017 - Jeremy Howard has studied machine learning for 25 years. He says artificial intelligence can help achieve amazing things. But he warns the impact on jobs may cause a great deal of social instability. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/21/524702525/jeremy-howard-will-artificial-intelligence-be-the-last-human-invention

item.title: Is It Safe To Eat Moldy Bread?
item.description: April 21, 2017 - No, say food safety experts. Molds can easily penetrate deep into a soft food, like bread. But you can salvage other foods with tougher surfaces, like cabbages, carrots and hard cheeses.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 21, 2017 - No, say food safety experts. Molds can easily penetrate deep into a soft food, like bread. But you can salvage other foods with tougher surfaces, like cabbages, carrots and hard cheeses. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/21/523647669/is-it-safe-to-eat-moldy-bread

item.title: When It Comes To Policymaking, The Rules Don't Apply To Climate Change
item.description: April 20, 2017 - On Saturday, people from around the country will take to the streets in the March for Science. Organizers say that the point of the March is not to make science political, but to highlight the reality of science to politicians, as a guide in policymaking, in which science is an uncharted issue.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 20, 2017 - On Saturday, people from around the country will take to the streets in the March for Science. Organizers say that the point of the March is not to make science political, but to highlight the reality of science to politicians, as a guide in policymaking, in which science is an uncharted issue. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/20/524936065/when-it-comes-to-policymaking-the-rules-dont-apply-to-climate-change

item.title: Researchers Find Yet Another Reason Why Naked Mole-Rats Are Just Weird
item.description: April 20, 2017 - The hairless, ground-dwelling, cold-blooded rodents have proven capable of surviving total oxygen deprivation. Their odd biology allows them to run on an alternative fuel.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 20, 2017 - The hairless, ground-dwelling, cold-blooded rodents have proven capable of surviving total oxygen deprivation. Their odd biology allows them to run on an alternative fuel. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/20/524511231/researchers-find-yet-another-reason-why-naked-mole-rats-are-just-weird

item.title: Astronaut, Cosmonaut And Stuffed Dog Arrive At International Space Station
item.description: April 20, 2017 - It's the first mission to space for American Jack Fischer, who says there is one aspect of space station life that you can't train for on Earth: using a zero-gravity toilet.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 20, 2017 - It's the first mission to space for American Jack Fischer, who says there is one aspect of space station life that you can't train for on Earth: using a zero-gravity toilet. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/20/524883853/astronaut-cosmonaut-and-stuffed-dog-arrive-at-international-space-station

item.title: Electrical Stimulation To Boost Memory: Maybe It's All In The Timing
item.description: April 20, 2017 - Research in epilepsy has found a key to why small pulses of electricity to the brain sometimes help and sometimes hurt a failing memory. Brains hurt by physical trauma or dementia might benefit, too.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 20, 2017 - Research in epilepsy has found a key to why small pulses of electricity to the brain sometimes help and sometimes hurt a failing memory. Brains hurt by physical trauma or dementia might benefit, too. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/20/524374825/electrical-stimulation-to-boost-memory-maybe-its-all-in-the-timing
